newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgarian refinery maintains steady output.
newsitem.headline: Bulgarian refinery maintains steady output.

text.p: Bulgaria's biggest oil refinery, Neftohim, which supplies the whole domestic market, plans to process 600,000 tonnes of crude this month and a total of six million tonnes this year, plant officials said on Friday.
Neftohim's executive director Nikola Karagyozov said production, which totalled some 630,000 tonnes last month, was steady and daily refining volumes were about 20,000 tonnes.
"I think that now we meet 100 percent of the needs of the domestic market," Karagyozov told Reuters by telephone.
He said part of the oil deliveries this month would come from Rosbulneft, a Bulgarian-Russian joint venture between Neftohim and Rosneft.
He declined to name the other suppliers.
Karagyozov said the plant processed 5.4 million tonnes of crude in the first 10 months of the year.
Neftohim's initial plans were to raise total output this year by 310,000 tonnes to 7.65 million tonnes. But officials said the plant was expected to refine a total of six million tonnes this year.
Foreign firms, including South Korean companies, have offered to build a catalytic reformer, which is crucial for the enlargement of the plant's output, officials said.

The 31-year-old plant at the Black Sea port of Bourgas is now Bulgaria's only operating refinery after the sale of the Pleven-based plant Plama earlier this year. Last November Plama suspended production due to cash shortages.
Plama's new owner, Bulgaria's Euroenergy, said it planned to resume output in November.
